intro: Cochlioda sanguinea, commonly known as the red-stemmed cocklebur, is a flowering plant native to North America. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its distinctive, spiny fruit capsules. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and can be found in fields, roadsides, and along stream banks. Its leaves are heart-shaped with serrated edges, and its flowers are small, yellow, and clustered in composite heads. Cochlioda sanguinea is often considered a weed but has historical uses in traditional medicine.
